urls.title: Consumption of ozone-depleting substances
urls.description: In 2020, the EU continued to actively phase out ozone-depleting substances (ODS), in line with its commitment under the Montreal Protocol. Data for 2020 show that consumption of ODS in the EU remained negative (-2,023 metric tonnes), meaning that more substances were destroyed or exported than were produced or imported. The EU¬¥s consumption of these substances has been negative since 2012. For more information and data reported by companies under the Ozone Regulation,¬† see the online ODS data viewer .

@KlimaAction The #energytransition‚ö°Ô∏èmust be fair for all categories of population ‚Äì not just in certain countries. Climate policies, for example increasing the price of #fossilfuels to make #renewables more attractive, must include compensatory measures if they risk increasing inequalities.

@FFFMAPA #ZeroEmissions  means that emissions from all sources must be zero. Net zero means that we also count so-called sinks or removals. So there can still be some emissions from certain sources, as long as they are compensated by removals from sinks, so that the sum is ‚Äònet zero‚Äô.

@KlimaAction 2/ A carbon offset is a quantity of emissions that is saved thanks to a certain action or project (like insulating a house, installing solar panels, planting a üå≥, etc.). Offsets help compensating for emissions made elsewhere but they must meet certain criteria & be verified.

@KlimaAction 1/ A carbon budget is a limit set on the quantity of GHG that a country, a company or even a person can emit during a certain period. Just like a financial budget is the maximum amount of money that you can spend for a defined time period or project.  #ClimateChangeFacts

urls.title: Global and European sea level rise
urls.description: Global mean sea level (GMSL) has risen about 19¬†cm since 1900, at an accelerating rate. GMSL reached its highest value ever in 2019. Climate models project a GMSL rise during the 21st century that will likely be in the range of 0.29-0.59¬†m for a low emissions scenario and 0.61-1.10¬†m for a high one. GMSL projections that include the possibility of faster disintegration of the polar ice sheets predict a rise of up to 2.4¬†m in 2100 and up to 15¬†m in 2300. Most coastal regions in Europe have experienced an increase in sea level relative to land, except for the northern Baltic coast.

text: @KlimaAction #Palmoil has become very attractive for food manufacturing and as a biofuel. However, its cultivation generates environmental impacts, including #deforestation and #biodiversityloss, as well as social conflicts. Despite positive economic benefits, these remain serious concerns.

@FFF_Latam 3/ ...And by a factor of more than 100 or even 1000 in some locations during the 21st century, depending on the emissions scenario used. That's just a European example. Your countries may have their own scenarios. #ClimateChangeFacts #EarthDay

@Fridays4future 2/ Other sources of emissions (agriculture, air conditioning, landfills..) call for other solutions: using #lessfertilisers, recovering landfill gas, product substitution, etc. In the end, action must happen at all levels of our society: governments, cities, companies, citizens.

@FFF_Latam 2/Mean üåäsea level rise will contribute to projected increases in coastal floods along the European coast.  The frequency of #coastalflooding events is estimated to increase by more than a factor of 10 in many European locations ...

@FFF_Latam 1/ By the end of this century, under the low emissions scenario European coasts would experience mean üåäsea level rise between 0.2‚ÄØm and 0.4 m and under high emission scenario  between 0.4‚ÄØm and 1.0 m (based on some studies up to 2.5 m)! #ClimateChangeFacts

@Fridays4future 1/ Most of our emissions come from burning #fossilfuels (coal, gas, petrol) to produce #electricity, heat our homes or transport people and goods. So we must cut down our energy use, waste less energy and switch to renewable energy sources in all these different sectors.

@Fridays4future Hi there! @IPCC_CH  defines #climatechange as a change in the state of the climate. Current changes in climate are consequences of #humanactivities such as emissions of GHG & changes in land use. Impacts of #climatechange like extreme events affect nature, our health, economy
